entry.title: Combined summary - A Note on Public Communication
entry.summary: The Lightning-dev mailing list has been experiencing low activity due to off-topic emails and limited moderation. One member expressed concern over the potential death of the mailing list and asked if there was a better place for discussions. Another member highlighted the importance of public communication for technical discussions in order to document the range of options considered and provide opportunities for new participants to contribute. They emphasized IRC, the mailing list, and GitHub issues/PRs as the primary channels for such communication. It is important to note that this discussion took place on the Lightning-dev mailing list and was made available through associated links.When the author first joined the lightning community, they were new to open source software and specification work. They were impressed by Rusty on the importance of holding conversations in public, which includes IRC, mailing lists, and GitHub issues/PRs. This helps document technical decisions and allows new participants to contribute to discussions. The author believes that it is important to reiterate the preference for public communication whenever possible, especially for specification or technical discussions, in response to recent emails posted on the list.There is concern over the state of public communication in a certain mailing list, which has become barren since one off-topic email was sent. There appears to be a backlog of emails with only one moderator checking them once a week, leading to discussions on whether there is a better place for such conversations. The importance of holding conversations as much as possible in public was emphasized by a member of the lightning community, citing its usefulness in documenting technical decisions and providing an interface point for new participants to contribute to the discussion. It is therefore crucial for technical or specification discussions to be held publicly to ensure transparency and inclusivity.Michael Folkson has suggested that lightning-dev mailing list requires more moderators due to the increased number of emails on the bitcoin-dev mailing list. He believes that although Bitcoin and Lightning discussions are becoming more intertwined, it is best to keep both lists separate. Recently, one off-topic email sent to the lightning-dev mailing list led to a decrease in communication and only one moderator checking them once a week, which may cause the list to die. However, Vincenzo Palazzo thinks the list is the most accessible way for communication as it allows people to search for some history and implement ideas proposed in the future. Vincent agrees to change the communication tools if they do not lose two properties.Antoine Riard, a Bitcoin developer, has written a response to Tony Giorgio's suggestion that there is a better place for public communication, stating that the Bitcoin and Lightning development communication channels constitute a public forum where participants are exchanging ideas and defending competing interests. In his post of March 21, Antoine had expressed concerns of "frivolous legal claims" being used between bitcoin developers/organizations provoking a distortion of the neutrality of the development, and a chilling effect of the technical discussions. He further explained that it was his legal right and moral duty to inform the community of what is happening between Chaincode and himself. He also stated that the maintainers of those communication channels should ensure a balance of rights and a proportionality in any restraining measure.Keags sent an email to Jorge Timón, advising him to be mindful of his words when communicating on the mailing list. Keags warned that some readers may not understand the drama that Jorge is referencing and his overt antagonism may cause suspicion among readers. He suggested that Jorge communicate in a way that recruits allies and demonstrates good faith if he wishes to affect change. Keags also advised Jorge to take greater care in seeing how his words are understood by others, as this could elicit greater sympathy and cooperation.Several members of the Lightning-dev mailing list have engaged in an email exchange discussing various topics related to open-source development and community communication. One member, Jorge Timón, challenges Jeremy Rubin to a public debate to defend himself against accusations of being "clearly delusional." Antoine Riard defends his right to share personal information on a public forum and emphasizes the need for proportionality in restricting participants' rights to contribute and speak their minds. Another member, Tony Giorgio, questions if there is a better place for public communication than the mailing list. Meanwhile, niftynei stresses the importance of holding conversations in public to document technical decisions and provide opportunities for new participants to join the discussion. The context highlights the need for the Lightning community to focus on technical topics and avoid getting involved in personal conflicts that can damage the community's ability to discuss and exchange ideas.
